Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Evaluating Capabilities of Neural Control in Human-Machine Interaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to evaluate quantitatively the capabilities of human operators in human-machine interaction (HMI). The research approach consists of two parts. In the first part, the human operator is viewed as a hybrid neural controller. The capabilities of the neural controller are evaluated based on physiological constraints and modeled functions of the neural system. In the second part, the human operator is viewed as an information processor and a communication channel. The capacity of the neural system is quantified in terms of rate of information exchanges between the human and the machine. These two parts offer complementary views and synergistically combines control theory, information theory, computational neuroscience, non-invasive human experiments, and computer simulations in the study of human-in-the-loop control systems.

If successful, the results of this research will provide quantitative indications of the effectiveness of HMI and fundamental limitations of the human controller. This will be instructive to discard impossible designs or specifications, determine system controllability or task achievability, and design HMI interfaces that may maximally utilize human control commands. This research will also promote the understanding of neural organization and mechanism for movement control, learning, and information processing. These neural principles will inspire new concepts and techniques for intelligent and advanced control. The educational component of this project will create more opportunities for students and working engineers to appreciate the importance of human factors and to learn techniques to handle these factors in engineering system design. A new student chapter of IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society will be instituted to facilitate student involvement in research and professional activities related to human-centered design in real engineering world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complexity of human-machine interaction (HMI) grows rapidly in modern industrial, medical, and military systems. However, there is no quantitative indication of the human capacity and cognitive workload in those challenging HMI tasks. The research objective of this project is to evaluate quantitatively the capabilities of the human neural system in manual control and decision-making.

First, we proposed a framework to quantify (in terms of information-transmission rate) the human capability in manual control of systems with complex dynamics. We showed that the information-transmission rate varied with the degree of instability of the system under control and the time delay present in the closed-loop system. For example, we derived that, in stabilizing unstable systems, the information transmission from the human to the machine via hand manipulation of one degree of freedom (e.g., driving a steering wheel or controlling an inverted pendulum restricted in a plane) is limited by 4 bits per second. We demonstrated in an experiment involving human control of an inverted pendulum that the information rate of human manual control decreases with the amount of time delay in the feedback loop and increases for the pendulum with reduced length.

Second, we investigated the difficulties that human operators face in regard to the feedback design limitations. We identified the situations when human control reaches its limits given certain performance requirements. If the human operator maneuvers an unstable system, the frequency response of the control movements must be formed in such a manner that a lower bound of the bandwidth of the feedback system is satisfied. Thus unstable systems demand the human operator to generate higher frequency movements in order to achieve certain required performance. If time delay is present in human control, an upper bound must be imposed on the bandwidth of the feedback system. If we consider the time delay to be the neuromuscular lag of 150 ms, then we obtain a bandwidth limitation of 2 Hz which is consistent with the assumed human bandwidth.

Third, we developed a magnetic tracking system for finger motion capture. This system consisted of a set of permanent magnets (in the form of artificial fingernails) and an electric wristband. A combined magnetic field was established by the magnets and varied with the finger movements. Multiple magnetic sensors, which were distributed around the wrist, detect magnetic flux at their predetermined positions. The measured data were used to inversely calculate finger postures: we developed a source localization algorithm to calculate finger postures. This system provides us a test-bed to capture hand motion and examine manual control in human-machine interaction.
